questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented with chronic back pain and neck stiffness. An X-ray cervical spine is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Etiology

Unknown; associated with metabolic conditions (e.g., diabetes)

Radiological Features

Continuous flowing ossifications over vertebral bodies, preservation of disc spaces

Common Location

Cervical and thoracic spine

Symptoms

Stiffness, chronic pain, dysphagia if cervical involvement

Differential Diagnosis

Ankylosing spondylitis, degenerative disc disease

Management

Symptomatic treatment with NSAIDs, physical therapy

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient presented with complaints of fever and cough. His chest radiograph shows an air bronchogram sign. The probable diagnosis is :
questions.explanation: Correct Option B.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis based on the image of the scan given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D: Craniopharyng

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 50-year-old female patient who shows a progressive decline in visual clarity in her eye? A post-contrast CT scan of her head indicates the presence of thickening in a specific structure, in the image.
Identify the labelled structure in the image?
A patient complains of neck stiffness and severe headache. The CT image shown below is suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Presence of blood in the subarachnoid space, typically from a ruptured cerebral aneurysm or trauma.

Clinical Features
  • Sudden, severe headache (often described as a "thunderclap headache")
  • Worst headache ever experienced by the patient.

Etiology
  • Traumatic: Head injuries causing bleeding in the subarachnoid space.
  • Non-Traumatic: Most commonly due to rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.

Initial Imaging

Non-Contrast CT (NCCT): First-line imaging for suspected SAH, effective in the acute setting.

Radiological Findings (NCCT)

Appearance of Blood: Hyperdense (white) compared to surrounding cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

Common Sites for Blood Accumulation:

  • Interhemispheric Fissure
  • Sylvian Fissure
  • Suprasellar Cistern
  • Perimesencephalic Cistern

Distinctive Shape: Blood may take on a pentagon or star shape, referred to as the "Star of Death."

Additional Investigations

CT Angiography: Visualizes potential aneurysms or vascular malformations; useful for rupture suspicion.

Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA): Gold standard for diagnosing cerebral aneurysms; provides detailed vascular images and therapeutic options (e.g., endovascular coiling).

questions.text: A cystic lesion in the suprasellar region with calcification is seen on the MRI. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Craniopharyngioma

  • Craniopharyngiomas are suprasellar tumors that develop from remnants of the craniopharyngeal duct or Rathke’s pouch.
  • It compress Optic chaism leads to bitemporal hemianopia.
  • Adamantinomatous subtype
    • It is more common
    • Seen in children
    • Typically appear as large, lobulated, multiloculated cystic lesions with a small enhancing solid component and calcifications.
  • Papillary subtype
    • Seen in Adults
    • Primarily solid lesion
    • Rarely exhibit calcifications

Pituitary Adenoma (Option B)

Pituitary Microadenomas

  • Less than 10 mm in size.
  • Microadenomas appear isointense to the pituitary on T1-weighted images and slightly hyperintense on T2-weighted images.
  • In dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI, they enhance slowly compared to the surrounding pituitary gland.

Pituitary Macroadenomas

  • Larger than 10 mm in size.
  • Most of the macroadenomas are nonfunctioning.
  • They may cause endocrine disturbances or compress the optic chiasm, leading to bitemporal hemianopia.
  • Typically appear as sellar-suprasellar masses with a “snowman” or “figure of eight” appearance due to a waist at the diaphragma sellae.
  • The sella is usually enlarged.
  • These tumors can invade the cavernous sinuses.

Meningioma (Option C)
  • Meningiomas arise from arachnoidal cap cells in the brain and spinal cord coverings.
  • They are the most common benign intracranial tumors.
  • Most common in females
  • Mostly sporadic but can be linked to NF-2 or prior cranial irradiation.
  • Meningiomas are dural based extra-axial masses that appear isointense to gray matter on both T1 and T2-weighted images.
  • They demonstrate intense homogeneous enhancement on post-contrast imaging, accompanied by a dural tail sign.
  • Characteristic imaging features:
    • CSF cleft sign (thin layer of CSF around the mass)
    • Cortical buckling
    • Widening of the subarachnoid space with visible pial arteries/veins,
    • Hyperostosis or erosion of the calvarium.
    • Mother in law sign (early enhancement during the arterial phase and remain opacified long after the venous phase has passed)
    • Calcification

Oligodendroglioma (Option D)
  • Oligodendrogliomas are diffuse infiltrating glial tumors originating from oligodendrocytes and are characterized by IDH mutations and 1p/19q codeletion.
  • These tumors can be either WHO grade 2 (well-differentiated oligodendrogliomas) or WHO grade 3 (anaplastic oligodendrogliomas).
  • Typically occurs in the frontal lobe.
  • They are slow-growing, non-encapsulated, and tend to infiltrate the overlying cortex.
  • CT: Oligodendrogliomas are isodense to hypodense with calcification
  • MRI: Tumors are hypointense on T1 and hyperintense on T2. They generally do not enhance with contrast

questions.text: A 22-year-old male arrived at the emergency room after being involved in a car accident. During the examination, his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was E2M2V3, indicating a level of consciousness. No fractures, hydrocephalus, or increased pressure within the skull were detected. A non-contrast CT scan was conducted and showed no abnormalities. The probable diagnosis is-
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Etiology

High-speed trauma, rotational forces, falls

Mechanism

Shearing of axons due to rapid acceleration/deceleration

Clinical Features

Unconsciousness, low GCS, no focal deficits

Imaging Findings

Normal CT initially; MRI shows microhemorrhages (FLAIR, GRE sequences)

Management

Supportive care, ICU monitoring, neuroprotection

questions.text: An elderly man presents with a 7-month history of progressive dysphagia and bad breath. An image is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old male was brought to the emergency room after being involved in a car accident. During the examination, his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was E2M2V3. There were no fractures, hydrocephalus, or increased pressure within the skull. A non-contrast CT scan was conducted and revealed no abnormalities. The suspected diagnosis is
Which of the following MRI imaging techniques is shown in the image below?
questions.explanation:
MRI Sequence

CSF Appearance

Fat Appearance

Use Cases

T1-weighted

Dark

Bright

Anatomy, fat-containing lesions

T2-weighted

Bright

Darker

Edema, inflammation, tumors

FLAIR

Dark

Dark

White matter lesions, periventricular pathology

STIR

Dark

Dark

Suppresses fat signal, good for musculoskeletal imaging

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below.
A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling present since birth. The X-ray image is given below. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Caput Succedaneum

(Option C ruled out)

Cephalohematoma

(Option B)

Incidence

Common

Less common

Location

Subcutaneous plane

Over parietal bones, between the skull and periosteum.

Time of Presentation

Maximum size and firmness at birth.

Develops during the 1st few hours of life. Increasing size for 12-24 hours and then stable.

Time Course

Softens progressively from birth.

Takes 3-6 weeks to resolve, but may resolve within 2-3 days.

Characteristic Findings
  • Diffuse Circular boggy area of oedema with indistinct borders.
  • Often with overlying ecchymosis
  • Crosses suture line
  • Well-circumscribed fluid-filled mass.
  • Does not cross the suture line

Association

None

Linear skull fracture (5-25%); hyperbilirubinemia

questions.text: A patient presented with a head injury after a hammer fell on the skull. CT is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct option C - Depressed skull fractu

questions.text: Identify the radiological image of the condition given below.
questions.explanation:
Osteoporosis circumscripta: A circumscribed patch of osteoporosis in the skull.

The cotton wool appearance of the skull (due to sclerosis)

Tam O'Shanter sign: The skull's expansion and flattened base create the appearance of the skull tilting over the facial structures (due to the thickening of the frontal bone).

 

Blade of grass appearance or candle flame sign: Flame-shaped lesion extending along the shaft of the bone.

Picture frame vertebra:

The vertebrae appear enlarged and have a thickened cortical bone due to excessive bone remodeling and disorganized osteoblastic activity.

 

Ivory vertebra:

The homogeneous, radiopaque appearance results from increased bone density caused by abnormal osteoblastic activity, leading to excessive bone formation.

 

Lincoln sign or Black Beard sign: Increased radiotracer uptake in the mandible gives it a distinctive black beard appearance that signifies abnormal bone metabolism in Paget’s disease.

Banana fractures: Occur in a region of abnormal bone.

questions.text: Which visual field defect is likely to be caused by the lesion shown in the given radiograph?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Bitemporal h

questions.text: Using the radiograph provided, which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Chiari type 1

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient complains of a persistent headache. A CT scan of the head was performed, as shown below. What is the most accurate diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

questions.text: From the provided MRI, please identify the medical condition observed in the lower back of the newborn, which presents as an abnormal lump.
questions.explanation: Correct Option A

questions.text: Match the following: A. Epidural hematoma i. B. Subdural hematoma ii. C. Subarchniod hemorrhage iii. D. Intracerebral hemorrhage iv.
questions.correct_answer: B. b. A-ii, B-iv, C-i, D-iii
questions.explanation:
Intracranial Hemorrhage

Key Features

Epidural Hematoma
  • Typically caused by arterial bleeding
  • Lens-shaped blood collection between the skull and the dura mater
  • Associated with head trauma or skull fracture

Subdural Hematoma
  • Typically caused by venous bleeding
  • Blood collection between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater
  • Can be acute, subacute, or chronic

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
  • Bleeding into the subarachnoid space
  • Can result from ruptured aneurysms or head trauma
  • Often presents with a sudden severe headache
  • May be associated with neck stiffness or photophobia

Intracerebral Hemorrhage
  • Bleeding within the brain tissue itself
  • Can be caused by hypertension, trauma, or other underlying conditions
  • Symptoms depend on the location and extent of the bleed, such as weakness, numbness, or changes in consciousness

questions.text: Please determine the anatomical structure indicated in the provided MRI scan.
A child presents with left to right shunt and high output cardiac failure . The following is his MRA . What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A: Vein of G

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the shown CT:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B

Type of Brain Hemorrhage

Appearance on CT Scan

Epidural Hemorrhage

Convex, lens-shaped collection of blood located between the skull and the dura mater. Appears hyperdense.

Subdural Hemorrhage

Crescent-shaped collection of blood between the dura mater and the brain. Appears hyperdense.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

Diffuse or localized areas of high-density blood within the subarachnoid space.

Intracerebral Hemorrhage

Irregular-shaped areas of high-density blood within the brain tissue.

Intraventricular Hemorrhage

Hyperdense areas of blood accumulation within the brain's ventricles.

Traumatic Extradural Hemorrhage

Collection of blood between the skull and the dura mater caused by trauma. Appears hyperdense.

Hypertensive Intracerebral Hemorrhage

Areas of high-density blood within the brain tissue, often in deep structures like the basal ganglia.

Aneurysmal Subarachnoid Hemorrhage

Diffuse or localized areas of high-density blood within the subarachnoid space, typically associated with the rupture of an intracranial aneurysm.
